<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TELECOM
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/09/09/elliott-management-discloses-stake-airs-grievances-att?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Elliott and AT&T Become the Worst Kind of Pen Pals
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Elliott and AT&T Become the Worst Kind of Pen Pals" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTY4MDUzODc0LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em><div>
<a href="https://www.flickr.com/photos/jeepersmedia/16162680598/" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"></a>"<a href="https://www.flickr.com/photos/jeepersmedia/16162680598/" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">AT&T ATandT</a>" (<a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0/" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">CC BY 2.0</a>) by <a href="https://www.flickr.com/people/jeepersmedia/" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">JeepersMedia</a>
</div></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The activist investor Elliott Management <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/09/business/dealbook/att-activist-investor.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">revealed</a> yesterday that it owns $3.2 billion in AT&T stock, or just over 1% of the company. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">That's the investor part, here’s the activist part.</strong> In a letter to the AT&T (+1.49%) board, Elliott called AT&T “<a href="https://activatingatt.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Elliotts-Letter-to-ATT_09092019.pdf?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">deeply undervalued</a>” and laid out a four-part strategy to improve the company’s operations and boost its share price by 65%. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Some background on Elliott: </strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>It’s not even run by a guy named Elliott. The huge investment firm was founded by Paul Singer in 1977 and, </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/elliott-management-discloses-3-2-billion-stake-in-at-t-11568031530?mod=hp_lead_pos1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">according to the WSJ</a></span><span>, last year waged the equivalent of almost one new public activism campaign every two weeks.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>It’s one of very few activists with the resources and chutzpah to take on a $271 billion telecom giant like AT&T.</span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Elliott’s airing of grievances for AT&T</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Goes like this... </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Misguided M&A strategy: </strong>AT&T is the shopper who tries on clothes that don’t fit...but buys them anyway. In 2014, it bought DirecTV for almost $50 billion at the “absolute peak of the linear TV market.” Most recently, it acquired the media powerhouse Time Warner for $85 billion. So far there’s <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-09-09/at-t-stock-is-targeted-by-elliott-deservedly?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">not much to show for it</a> besides a mountain of debt.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Execution: </strong>In one example, AT&T missed an opportunity to create a “game-changing product experience” when it acquired exclusive rights to distribute the iPhone in 2007 but failed to scale it accordingly. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Retention: </strong>Nearly all of Time Warner’s c-suite has left following the acquisition, including HBO’s legendary CEO Richard Plepler. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Looking ahead...</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You don’t buy $3.2 billion of a company without sensing opportunities for improvement. Elliott thinks AT&T has an enviable wireless business and a “world-class” collection of assets, but it hasn’t realized its potential under CEO Randall Stephenson. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">AT&T is looking forward to "engaging with Elliott" much like the way you look forward to a colonoscopy.</p>

<tr>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
WORKFORCE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/09/09/many-companies-hiring?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
There Are So Many Companies Hiring…
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="There Are So Many Companies Hiring…" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/jUPhtlcEpstMLWVzU6/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="There Are So Many Companies Hiring…" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/jUPhtlcEpstMLWVzU6/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">...you could probably bring John C. Reilly into your interview and still score the job. <a href="https://media.giphy.com/media/jUPhtlcEpstMLWVzU6/giphy.gif?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"></a></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Amazon </strong>(-0.12%) could hire the entire undergraduate enrollment of the University of Michigan—it said it has <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/09/technology/amazon-30000-job-openings.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">30,000 open positions</a>. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>That's the most open positions Amazon has ever had.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Over half the jobs are tech-focused.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The jobs are full- and part-time.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Jim Harbaugh, you should def apply.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">UPS </strong>(+1.32%) is hiring <a href="https://apnews.com/ae3a4c2e888d4b919457c5e88603df57?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">about 100,000</a> seasonal workers to handle the holiday rush from Thanksgiving through January, when UPS package volume roughly doubles. Because of a new labor deal, UPS <a href="https://fortune.com/2019/09/09/ups-jobs-hiring-100000-seasonal-employment/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">is offering</a> $14–$30/hour for seasonal hires, up from $10.10 on average last year.<a href="https://media.giphy.com/media/jUPhtlcEpstMLWVzU6/giphy.gif?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><br></a></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Uber </strong>(+1.19%) will spend at least $2 billion over the next decade to expand its freight business in Chicago. It’ll <a href="https://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-biz-uber-hiring-old-post-office-20190909-va4mtjmgkfh7bnlrub736fbw5q-story.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hire 2,000 employees</a> in three years to leverage its Uber Freight network of <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/6fa14cbc-d034-11e9-b018-ca4456540ea6?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">400,000 drivers</a> in the U.S.<a href="https://media.giphy.com/media/jUPhtlcEpstMLWVzU6/giphy.gif?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><br></a></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>The labor market is tight—meaning all companies have to sweeten the deal to win workers during a time of generation-low unemployment.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HOUSING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/09/09/fannie-mae-freddie-mac-comeback-trail?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
A Tale of Redemption: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="A Tale of Redemption: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTY4MjI2Mzc1LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em><a href="https://www.fanniemae.com/portal/media/resources.html" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Fannie Mae</a></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Act I) </strong>Last Friday, a federal appeals court <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/investors-notch-victory-over-fannie-freddie-profits-11567879840?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">challenged</a> the government's decision to require Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to send their profits to the Treasury Department. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Act II)</strong> Yesterday, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin <a href="https://www.foxbusiness.com/markets/treasury-secretary-steven-mnuchin-trump-administration-fannie-mae-freddie-mac-reform?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said on Fox Business</a> he’s close to an agreement that would allow Fannie and Freddie to keep their earnings for themselves. Don’t roll your eyes—that’s considered an important step toward the re-privatization of the mortgage finance giants.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory:</strong> Fannie and Freddie, both of which wrap mortgages into securities investors can purchase, <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-fannie-and-freddie-have-changed-since-the-crisis-11567953001?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">have been</a> under federal control since they got a $190 billion taxpayer bailout during the housing crisis. The Obama administration imposed a controversial “net worth sweep” in 2012, which meant almost all their profits went to the Treasury. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>For the past seven years, that sweep has frustrated investors (including many hedge funds) who bet that Fannie and Freddie would one day be allowed to roam free. The court decision coupled with Mnuchin’s newsworthy interview means that day <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-09-09/mnuchin-expects-deal-on-fannie-freddie-retaining-earnings-soon-k0cdynmy?srnd=premium&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">could be approaching</a>. </p>

<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2019%2F09%2F09%2Ffannie-mae-freddie-mac-comeback-trail" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TAXES
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/09/09/40-fdi-phantom-capital-says-new-report?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Phantom of the FDI
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="No Alt" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MTMwL2x1eGVtYm91cmdjaXR5dmlld19qcGcuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>User:Sixdown, LuxembourgCityView, CC BY-SA 3.0</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Almost 40% of the world’s total foreign direct investment is in so-called "<a href="https://www.ft.com/content/37aa9d06-d0c8-11e9-99a4-b5ded7a7fe3f?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">phantom</a>" capital engineered to shrink tax bills—not boost international business, <a href="https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/fandd/2019/09/pdf/the-rise-of-phantom-FDI-in-tax-havens-damgaard.pdf?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">per a new study</a> from the IMF and the University of Copenhagen.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Breaking it down: </strong>Foreign direct investment (FDI) is when a firm or individual in one country <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/f/fdi.asp?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">invests in</a> business interests in another country. It is <em>not </em>you buying a knockoff Giants jersey from China. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The $15 trillion of phantom capital, equivalent to the combined annual GDP of China and Germany, “passes through empty corporate shells” with “no real business activities.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What’s actually going on: </strong>It looks like firms are squirreling away $$$ in international tax havens under the guise of foreign investment. The study found nearly half of phantom FDI flows to Luxembourg and the Netherlands—countries <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tax_haven?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">known as much</a> for their friendly corporate tax structures as their bouneschlupp and stroopwafels.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>With just 600,000 people, Luxembourg and its “miniscule” economy receive as much FDI as the U.S. and dwarf China’s tally.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The $4 trillion in FDI flowing into Luxembourg translates to $6.6 million per person, </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-09-09/tax-dodgers-phantom-cash-makes-up-40-of-foreign-investment?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Bloomberg points out</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
</ul>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2019%2F09%2F09%2F40-fdi-phantom-capital-says-new-report" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">
<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e865734bf6f7.jpg">
</a><span>  </span>
<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Firms+are+squirreling+away+%24%24%24+in+international+tax+havens&url=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/09/09/40-fdi-phantom-capital-says-new-report&via=MorningBrew" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BOOKS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/09/09/september-10-publishers-paradise?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Amazon Was a Little Too Excited for <em>The Handmaid's Tale </em>Sequel
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Amazon Was a Little Too Excited for <em>The Handmaid's Tale </em>Sequel" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=316 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/xT9IguxOugw6KwaANy/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Amazon Was a Little Too Excited for <em>The Handmaid's Tale </em>Sequel" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/xT9IguxOugw6KwaANy/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Bedside table looking lonely? <em>The Testaments, </em>Margaret Atwood’s sequel to her 1985 global hit <em>The Handmaid’s Tale</em>, officially drops today.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The return to Gilead wasn't smooth. </strong>Last week, Amazon accidentally <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/05/us/margaret-atwood-amazon-handmaids-tale-sequel.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">shipped</a> <span>about </span>800 U.S. copies of <em>The Testaments</em> early. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Amazon apologized for the error, but that wasn’t enough for some independent booksellers. They complained that the mistake gave Amazon an edge since </span><span><span>smaller retailers</span></span><span> respected the publisher’s embargo. Booksellers are often penalized in some form for </span><span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2019/sep/04/margaret-atwoods-handmaid-s-tale-sequel-tight-secrecy-the-testaments?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">violating</a></span><span> an embargo.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Hulu and MGM will develop <em>The Testaments</em> for TV, though they haven’t figured out if they’ll work it into the existing <em>The Handmaid’s Tale</em> series. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But Atwood’s latest is just one of the many highly anticipated books being released today. Also noteworthy...</p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Garrett Graff’s </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-only-plane-in-the-sky-and-fall-and-rise-review-out-of-the-blue-on-sept-11-11567782975?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">oral history</a></span><span> of 9/11, </span><span><em>The Only Plane In The Sky</em></span><span>, on the eve of the tragedy’s 18th anniversary.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><em>She Said</em></span><span> is </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/08/books/harvey-weinstein-book-kantor-twohey.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">a book about</a></span><span> Harvey Weinstein’s serial sexual abuse. Its authors, Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey, are the NYT reporters who broke the Weinstein story.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Malcolm Gladwell’s newest nonfiction, </span><span><em>Talking To Strangers</em></span><span>. This one’s </span><span><a href="https://www.npr.org/2019/09/09/757508763/in-talking-to-strangers-malcolm-gladwell-explores-why-its-so-hard-to-do?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">about communication</a></span><span> and miscommunication.</span>
</li>
</ol>

href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/jeepersmedia/16162680598/\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAT\u0026T ATandT\u003c/a\u003e\" (\u003ca cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe activist investor Elliott Management \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/09/business/dealbook/att-activist-investor.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erevealed\u003c/a\u003e yesterday that it owns $3.2 billion in AT\u0026T stock, or just over 1% of the company. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThat's the investor part, here’s the activist part.\u003c/strong\u003e In a letter to the AT\u0026T (+1.49%) board, Elliott called AT\u0026T “\u003ca href=\"https://activatingatt.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Elliotts-Letter-to-ATT_09092019.pdf?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edeeply undervalued\u003c/a\u003e” and laid out a four-part strategy to improve the company’s operations and boost its share price by 65%. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSome background on Elliott: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIt’s not even run by a guy named Elliott. The huge investment firm was founded by Paul Singer in 1977 and, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/elliott-management-discloses-3-2-billion-stake-in-at-t-11568031530?mod=hp_lead_pos1\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eaccording to the WSJ\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, last year waged the equivalent of almost one new public activism campaign every two weeks.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIt’s one of very few activists with the resources and chutzpah to take on a $271 billion telecom giant like AT\u0026T.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eElliott’s airing of grievances for AT\u0026T\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eGoes like this... \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMisguided M\u0026A strategy: \u003c/strong\u003eAT\u0026T is the shopper who tries on clothes that don’t fit...but buys them anyway. In 2014, it bought DirecTV for almost $50 billion at the “absolute peak of the linear TV market.” Most recently, it acquired the media powerhouse Time Warner for $85 billion. So far there’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-09-09/at-t-stock-is-targeted-by-elliott-deservedly?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enot much to show for it\u003c/a\u003e besides a mountain of debt.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eExecution: \u003c/strong\u003eIn one example, AT\u0026T missed an opportunity to create a “game-changing product experience” when it acquired exclusive rights to distribute the iPhone in 2007 but failed to scale it accordingly. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eRetention: \u003c/strong\u003eNearly all of Time Warner’s c-suite has left following the acquisition, including HBO’s legendary CEO Richard Plepler. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYou don’t buy $3.2 billion of a company without sensing opportunities for improvement. Elliott thinks AT\u0026T has an enviable wireless business and a “world-class” collection of assets, but it hasn’t realized its potential under CEO Randall Stephenson. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAT\u0026T is looking forward to \"engaging with Elliott\" much like the way you look forward to a colonoscopy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c/strong\u003eLast Friday, a federal appeals court \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/investors-notch-victory-over-fannie-freddie-profits-11567879840?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003echallenged\u003c/a\u003e the government's decision to require Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to send their profits to the Treasury Department. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAct II)\u003c/strong\u003e Yesterday, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin \u003ca href=\"https://www.foxbusiness.com/markets/treasury-secretary-steven-mnuchin-trump-administration-fannie-mae-freddie-mac-reform?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid on Fox Business\u003c/a\u003e he’s close to an agreement that would allow Fannie and Freddie to keep their earnings for themselves. Don’t roll your eyes—that’s considered an important step toward the re-privatization of the mortgage finance giants.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory:\u003c/strong\u003e Fannie and Freddie, both of which wrap mortgages into securities investors can purchase, \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-fannie-and-freddie-have-changed-since-the-crisis-11567953001?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehave been\u003c/a\u003e under federal control since they got a $190 billion taxpayer bailout during the housing crisis. The Obama administration imposed a controversial “net worth sweep” in 2012, which meant almost all their profits went to the Treasury. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eFor the past seven years, that sweep has frustrated investors (including many hedge funds) who bet that Fannie and Freddie would one day be allowed to roam free. The court decision coupled with Mnuchin’s newsworthy interview means that day \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-09-09/mnuchin-expects-deal-on-fannie-freddie-retaining-earnings-soon-k0cdynmy?srnd=premium\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecould be approaching\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS It is \u003cem\u003enot \u003c/em\u003eyou buying a knockoff Giants jersey from China. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe $15 trillion of phantom capital, equivalent to the combined annual GDP of China and Germany, “passes through empty corporate shells” with “no real business activities.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat’s actually going on: \u003c/strong\u003eIt looks like firms are squirreling away $$$ in international tax havens under the guise of foreign investment. The study found nearly half of phantom FDI flows to Luxembourg and the Netherlands—countries \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tax_haven?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eknown as much\u003c/a\u003e for their friendly corporate tax structures as their bouneschlupp and stroopwafels.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWith just 600,000 people, Luxembourg and its “miniscule” economy receive as much FDI as the U.S. and dwarf China’s tally.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe $4 trillion in FDI flowing into Luxembourg translates to $6.6 million per person, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca
